title: Tips to trace your family history beyond DNA tests
text:
WASHINGTON – Searching for your family history can be challenging and frustrating, but it can also be exciting and fulfilling especially when you connect the dots.

I spent part of the summer researching my family roots. It was eye-opening.

“Be prepared to learn so much more than you could have ever imagined,’’ said Simone Jones, director of data analytics for AfricanAncestry.com. “Just embrace the research – and it’s OK to be overwhelmed.”

Here are five lessons I learned on my brief journey:

Tap older family members for stories and memories. My older cousins proved to be invaluable in finding where to start and to confirm information.

My older cousins proved to be invaluable in finding where to start and to confirm information. Don’t sleep on the U.S. Census. It can be a key source for figuring out where your family lived and who was in that household. Some information, including the spelling of names, can be wrong, so crosscheck with other resources.

It can be a key source for figuring out where your family lived and who was in that household. Some information, including the spelling of names, can be wrong, so crosscheck with other resources. Ask the librarian. I can’t tell you how many times researchers and librarians helped or pointed me to a great resource. Clerks at the county records offices were also helpful. Visit different libraries because they may have different information and resources.

I can’t tell you how many times researchers and librarians helped or pointed me to a great resource. Clerks at the county records offices were also helpful. Visit different libraries because they may have different information and resources. Get organized. Author Tony Burroughs cautioned that you should catalog and organize as you do your research. I listened, and it helped big time.

Author Tony Burroughs cautioned that you should catalog and organize as you do your research. I listened, and it helped big time. Search for birth certificates and other vital records, which can lead to useful information, such as the names of parents and where they were born. My place of birth on my daughter’s birth certificate is wrong. I never changed it. You can bet I will now because anyone searching my history will think I was born in Washington, D.C., instead of Brooklyn, New York.

Here are good resources:

Afro-American Historical and Genealogical Society (AAHGS), https://www.aahgs.org/

"Black Roots: A Beginner's Guide to Tracing the African American Family Tree,” by Tony Burroughs

Library of Virginia, http://www.lva.virginia.gov/

Library of Congress, https://www.loc.gov/search/?in=&q=genealogy&new=true&st=

The National Museum of African American History and Culture, https://nmaahc.si.edu/

The U.S. Census, https://www.census.gov/prod/www/decennial.html

Ancestry, https://www.ancestry.com/cs/african-american

AfricanAncestry.com, http://www.africanancestry.com/home/

Family Search, https://www.familysearch.org/en/

Daughters of the American Revolution, https://www.dar.org/
description: Researching your family history can be a daunting task, especially for African Americans. Here are some tips to find more about your genealogy and family history.
